content.webTitle: The Fiver | Paul Scholes and that breach of football betting regulations

fields.headline: Paul Scholes and that breach of football betting regulations
fields.bodyText: A STORY ABOUT SOME PUNTS Reading the story detailing how Paul Scholes was hauled before the Football Association beaks to answer questions about his fondness for an occasional punt on football, one sentence leapt out at The Fiver. “The FA became aware of Scholes’s behaviour after being informed of his betting history by the bookmaker Paddy Power at the turn of this year,” it read. Paddy Power, eh? How heartwarming to learn that, for all their zany, b@nterific attention-seeking and in-no-way-tasteless dedication to jolly japes, this behemoth of the bookmaking industry was quick to flag up what they recognised as a potential breach of football betting regulations to the FA, as they are duty-bound to do. Moving with the speed they normally reserve for flagging up winning punters and dramatically reducing the amounts they are allowed to bet with their firm, the narks at Power Towers provided information which has led to the former Manchester United midfielder being fined £8,000 and warned over his future conduct. His crime? Placing 140 bets worth £26,159 on football matches during his time as a director of Salford City when such behaviour is not allowed. Unwittingly, by his own account, Scholes had fallen foul of a somewhat over-the-top FA rule that precludes all those working in the English football pyramid, from the Premier League down to the Isthmian League, from gambling on any match taking place anywhere on the planet. “I accept [the] ruling,” said Scholes, for whom, to borrow a phrase from the gambling adverts, the fun has stopped. “I would like to apologise and I understand and fully accept the fine imposed by the FA. It was a genuine mistake and was not done with any deliberate intention to flout the rules. I wrongly believed that as long as there was no personal connection between me and any of the matches that I bet upon then there would be no issue.” To be clear, there is no suggestion whatsoever that Scholes, who quit as a director of Salford to take a job as Oldham manager he has since left, was benefitting from inside information from any of his many contacts in the game and his contrition seems genuine. However, he has learned the hard way that he will no longer be allowed to place a bet on football if he resumes working in the English game. In a sport where temptation is everywhere, due in no small part to the FA having no problem whatsoever with multiple bookmakers hosing cash at the sport to encourage current and potential problem gamblers, we wish him well. FIVER LETTERS “When you said that ‘good owners are as rare as unfunny tea-timely emails about football’ (yesterday’s Fiver), did you mean that one turns up late every day or (more likely) that they’re nowhere to be seen come the weekend?” – David Maddock. “Loving the inappropriate Google search terminology (Fiver letters passim). Last year my mother [of course – Fiver Ed] was researching how to do her own patio, which requires hardcore to be laid down first. She typed ‘hardcore spreading’ into Google, and was somewhat taken aback by the results” – Ben Letham. “Thank you Fiver for confirming that either: a) I have great predictive abilities; or b) you are very predictable. I’m pretty sure it’s the latter. It was only on Sunday that I was stating confidently to my husband that very soon we would see a reference to Frank Lampard’s Derby County’s Frank Lampard (yesterday’s Bits and Bobs), sending us into a spiral of confusion. I’m really looking forward to Frank Lampard’s Derby County’s Frank Lampard’s decision and whether any more apostrophes can be shoehorned into this” – Katie Maddock. “Re: yesterday’s letters. Surely Tin and tonic would be your drink of choice?” – Neale Redington. Send your letters to the.boss@theguardian.com. And you can always tweet The Fiver via @guardian_sport. Today’s winner of our letter o’the day is Ben Lethem, who wins a signed copy of From Delhi to The Den, by Stephen Constantine. NEWS, BITS AND BOBS Spain manager Luis Enrique is standing down due to personal reasons. “This is a bittersweet day, more bitter than sweet,” said Robert Moreno, taking over the gig. “I always dreamed of being Spain coach, but not like this.” Michel Platini has been released after being questioned by French plod over the award of the 2022 World Cup to Qatar. “It hurts for everything I can think of, everything I’ve done,” sniffed Uefa’s former chief suit. “This is an old affair, you know it, we explained it.” Another man hurting is Hamza Choudhury, who said “I don’t think I have ever felt worse in my footballing career” after his red card during England’s 2-1 defeat by France at the Euro U-21 Championship. “It wasn’t malicious and I didn’t want to hurt him,” he parped after re-popularising the Graeme Souness lunge on Jonathan Bamba’s ankle. “I have let the lads down, I have let the country down.” Atlético Madrid are close to shelling out €120m on Benfica forward João Félix. Mats Hummels continues to only sign for Bayern Munich or Borussia Dortmund. The good news just keeps on coming for Neymar: Uefa has upheld the three-match European ban he received for calling VAR officials a “disgrace” and telling them to “go [eff] yourselves!” during PSG’s Big Cup exit. It’s been almost too quiet at Birmingham City, so news of Garry Monk’s sacking has brought a certain normality back to St Andrew’s. And the Scottish FA has agreed a £5m deal with Queen’s Park to buy Hampden Park off them, meaning the Scottish League Two side will relocate to Lesser Hampden, the rickety little ground next door where a teenage Shortbread McFiver mis-spent his youth necking Buckfast.
